Graphical abstract Designing efficient and stable bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) electrocatalysts is important to developing renewable energy technologies. However, integrating OER/ORR activity in a single electrocatalyst remains challenging due to the difficulty in balancing the adsorption strengths of reaction intermediates. Herein, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate 4d-transition metal (TM) doped graphitic carbon nitride (4d-TM@C3N3) systems as potential bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts by considering the charge states through a defect physics method. Our results identified 30 stable 4d-TMN@C3N3 systems, including TM doped at nitrogen sites (4d-TMN@C3N3) and those occupying interstitial sites (4d-TMint@C3N3). Machine learning analysis showed that the the bond lengths between TM and O (d TM-O) and OH (d TM-OH), and the charge transfer of TM atoms (Q e) are the three primary descriptors characterizing the adsorption behavior. Among these, Pdint ×@C3N3 (Pd interstitial site, neutral charge state), Pdint •@C3N3 (Pd interstitial site, +1 charge state), and Rhint •@C3N3 (Rh interstitial site, +1 charge state) exhibit outstanding OER/ORR catalytic activity with η OER/η ORR of 0.56/0.37 V, 0.66/0.37 V, and 0.59/0.44 V, respectively, which are comparable to benchmark electrocatalysts such as RuO2 for OER (0.69 V) and Pt for ORR (0.61 V). The enhanced performance arises from charged defects adjustment that optimizes the bifunctional OER/ORR activity, offering potential electrocatalysts for energy conversion applications. Keywords Bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction Electrocatalysts Defect physics Density functional theory Machine learning Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The depletion of traditional fossil fuels and growing environmental pollution have compelled the pursuit of sustainable and clean energy solutions. Devices [1,2] that efficiently convert and store energy, such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries, have emerged as a viable solution to these challenges due to their high energy conversion efficiency, exceptional energy storage capacity, and low emissions of greenhouse gases [3,4]. Yet, the widespread adoption of such devices depends mainly on the effectiveness of oxygen electrode reactions, specifically the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). These reactions, unfortunately, are hindered by slow reaction rates, complex multi-step proton and electron transfer processes, and high overpotentials (η) [5]. Ongoing scientific research has led to the design of electrocatalysts to address these issues. For instance, Pt is highly efficient for ORR [6], IrO2 [7] and RuO2 [8] are top-tier electrocatalysts for OER. Nonetheless, these materials typically excel in only one reaction. Consequently, developing efficient and durable OER/ORR electrocatalysts – bifunctional electrocatalysts – is of paramount importance. Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N3) [9,10], a key member of the carbon nitride family, belongs to the covalent triazine framework category [11]. The synthesis of g-C3N3 is achievable at relatively low temperatures through the reaction of cyanuric chloride (C3N3Cl3) with reagents such as NaNH2, K, or NaN3 [10]. However, g-C3N3 is limited by its electrocatalytic performance due to poor electrical conductivity and high OER/ORR overpotentials. Hence, there is a pressing need to develop g-C3N3-based electrocatalysts with high efficiency and thermal and kinetic stability for bifunctional OER/ORR applications. To design efficient and durable bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts in g-C3N3, extensive theoretical studies have been devoted to exploring single-atom catalysts (SACs) with transition metals (TMs) anchored on g-C3N3. For example, Gao et al. [12] investigated TM@g-C3N3 (TM = Fe, Cu, Ru, and Ag) and found all configurations are stable, as indicated by the negative formation energies. They highlighted Pd@g-C3N3 as an effective bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalyst with low overpotentials of 0.41/0.19 V. Similarly, Chen et al. [13] employed density functional theory (DFT) to assess the bifunctional electrocatalytic activity of various TM@g-C3N3 configurations (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt, and Au). They identified Rh@g-C3N3 and Pd@g-C3N3 as top candidates for bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts. Furthermore, Lv et al. [14] recognized Co@g-C3N3 and Ni@g-C3N3 as effective SACs for OER in the context of water splitting, achieving remarkably low η OER/η ORR of 0.61/0.40 V, respectively. However, most studies have predominantly focused on neutral-state catalysts, overlooking the various charge states caused by point defects and impurities in semiconductors [15–17]. For instance, when 4d TM atoms substitute for C or N in the g-C3N3 lattice or occupy interstitial positions, the electrons are transferred into the g-C3N3 framework, disrupting the charge balance of TM@g-C3N3 [12,13,18]. In recent years, machine learning (ML) methods have been extensively utilized to enhance the understanding of electrocatalytic mechanisms [19,20]. Notably, Wang et al. [21] employed gradient-boosted regression, a technique within ML, to identify that the charge transfer of TM atoms (Qe ) and the total magnetic moment (μB0 ) are critical descriptors for predicting η OER/η ORR, respectively. Similarly, Yao et al. [22] leveraged ML to determine that the energy level of the εd and the number of 3d electrons (Ne ) are the most influential descriptors for η OER and η ORR, respectively. Therefore, ML is helpful to figure out the activity origin of the OER/ORR process on TM@g-C3N3. Here, we used first-principles calculations to design the 4d-TM@g-C3N3 systems considering charge states and machine learning (ML) to explore the factors that most impact the electrocatalytic OER/ORR performance. Among the systems studied, Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 (Pd interstitial site, neutral charge state), P d i n t ∙ @ C 3 N 3 (Pd interstitial site, +1 charge state), and R h i n t ∙ @ C 3 N 3 (Rh interstitial site, +1 charge state) demonstrate higher catalytic activity for both OER and ORR than other 4d-TM@g-C3N3 due to the moderate interaction with intermediates of *O and *OH. ML predictions conclude that the bond lengths between TM and O (d TM-O) and OH (d TM-OH) as well as the charge transfer of TM atoms (Q e) are the three primary descriptors characterizing the adsorption behavior. 2 Computational methods All first-principles calculations are carried out using spin-polarized DFT, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [23,24] code in this work, which is tested to be accurate enough with high efficiency. The ion–electron interaction is described by utilizing the projector augmented wave [25] basis set with a cutoff energy of 500 eV. Under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional is exploited to deal with the exchange–correlation interaction [26]. The energy convergence criterion is 10−4 eV, while the atomic force is set as 0.03 eV/Å to ensure the complete relaxation of all atomic positions. The geometric optimizations are performed using a Monkhorst-Pack [27] k-point mesh of 1 × 1 × 1, and the electronic structure calculations are performed using a 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh. To accurately describe the localized d orbitals transition metals, we use the GGA + U method [28] to test the U parameter's influence on the reaction intermediates' free energies. The solvation effect is considered by the VASPsol code with a dielectric constant of 78.4 to simulate the H2O solvent environment (GGA + SOL) [29]. Free energy correction for all intermediate species is performed with VASPKIT [30]. Charge transfer between TM atoms and g-C3N3 or TM@g-C3N3 and intermediates are analyzed by Bader charge analysis [31]. Based on the LOBSTER package, the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) [32] method is used to analyze the interaction strength between catalysts and intermediates. The figures are visualized and analyzed by using VESTA [33]. Analyzing neutral and charged systems by considering model defects expressed in Kröger-Vink notation [34]. This study employs the uniformly scaled supercell size approach to minimize the spurious Coulomb interactions in which the lateral lengths are equal (Lx = Ly = Lz, Fig. S1) [22,35–39]. The detailed formulas for the formation energy of defects are provided in Note S1. At the same time, the discussion about the chemical potentials is given in Note S2. The relevant data of formation energy calculation are listed in Tables S1–S4. The detailed formulas for the OER/ORR Gibbs free energy calculations in the acidic medium are provided in Note S3. The machine learning algorithms are performed in Python3 using the Scikit-learn package [40]. In our research, four different ML algorithms are used, namely gradient boosted regression (GBR) [41], random forest regression (RFR) [42], support vector regression (SVR), and k-neighbor regression (KNR) [43]. Additional details about these four algorithms can be found in Note S4. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Formation energy of 4d-TM@g-C3N3 In this study, we introduce impurity 4d-TM atoms (Zr, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag) into the g-C3N3 supercell via three modes (Fig. S2): 4d-TMC@g-C3N3 (doping at a C site), 4d-TMN@g-C3N3 (4d-TM doping at a N site), and 4d-TMint@C3N3 (occupying an interstitial site). As shown in Fig. S3, the formation energies of PdN@C3N3 are consistently lower than those of 4d-PdC@C3N3 under both C-rich and N-rich conditions, which indicates that 4d-TMs prefer to occupy the N position rather than the C position. Consequently, we select the N1 atom (Fig. S4) as the occupied site for 4d-TM atoms in subsequent investigations. For the 4d-TM interstitial site occupation, we consider 4d-TM atoms embedded in the central cavity, a configuration known to stabilize TM atoms [44,45], as exemplified by Pdint@C3N3 in Fig. S5. Under both N-rich and C-rich conditions, we computed the formation energies of 4d-TMN@C3N3 (Fig. S6) and 4d-TMint@C3N3 (Fig. S7) in various possible charge states (±2, ±1, and 0) as a function of the Fermi level to examine the convergence of the charge state. As depicted in Figs. S6 and S7, for both systems, the formation energies of the −2 charge state are higher than that of the −1 and 0 charge states when the charge state is negative. Similarly, the formation energies of the +2 charge state are all higher than that of the +1 and 0 charge states when the charge state is positive. These findings suggest the convergence of calculated charge states results, as unreasonable charge states exhibit higher formation energies. For enhanced clarity, we plotted the complete line for each charge state of each defect (Figs. S6 and S7) and highlighted the section where a specific charge state has the lowest formation energy, as summarized in Fig. 1 . Slope changes in these lines signify a shift in the defect's charge state. The results in Fig. 1a–d indicate that most 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems are stable with 0 and +1 charge states. Nbint@C54N54 and Zrint@C54N54 systems are also stable in a +2 charge state. Experimental conditions greatly influence the formation energy: under N-rich conditions, the formation energies of 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 are lower than those under C-rich conditions, meaning that N-rich growth conditions facilitate 4d TM atoms doping into g-C3N3. As summarized in Fig. 1e, thirty kinds of stable charge states were identified and considered in subsequent calculations to estimate their catalytic activity for bifunctional OER/ORR. 3.2 The potential-determining step In this section, we extend our analysis beyond the geometric structures, formation energies, and charge states of the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 to investigate their catalytic activity for the OER, ORR, and their combined bifunctional OER/ORR capabilities. OER and ORR, known as reverse processes, proceed via a four-electron associative mechanism [46,47] (Fig. S8). The Gibbs free energy changes of the oxygenated intermediates (ΔG *OH , ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH) are vital for determining their intrinsic catalytic activity towards OER/ORR [48–50]. We calculated the ΔG for each elementary reaction step, and our results indicate that all oxygenated intermediates preferentially adsorb at the TM sites with TM-O bonds in both 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3, as shown in Table S5, supporting insights from previous theoretical investigations [51–53]. Moreover, as shown in Table S5, the *OOH intermediates in the NbN@C3N3, Zrint@C3N3, Nbint@C3N3, and Moint@C3N3 dissociate into *O and *OH. Previous studies reported that the associative mechanism is more favorable for ORR on similar materials [54,55]. The dissociation mechanism of *OOH is thus not considered here. Consequently, ten catalysts (highlighted in red in Table S5) are excluded from further analysis. Subsequently, the free-energy changes for all elementary reactions on 4d-TM@g-C3N3 are calculated through Eqs. S14 and summarized in Table S6. Based on these results, the free-energy diagrams of the OER/ORR processes are depicted in Fig. S9 (U = 0 V) and S10 (U = 1.23 V). These diagrams illustrate the directional nature of the OER and ORR: the OER progresses from left to right, while the ORR proceeds in the reverse direction, from right to left. The reactivity of the OER and ORR processes is influenced by the energy differences between two consecutive oxygenated intermediates, which typically are not equal. This discrepancy often results in a reaction rate that is constrained by a specific elementary reaction, identified as the potential-determining step (PDS) [56,57]. The PDS is characterized by the maximum potential increase for the OER, whereas the minimum potential decrease defines the ORR. This pivotal step directly impacts catalyst activity, which the overpotential can quantify. The η metric is defined as the difference between the potential change at the PDS and the standard equilibrium potential of 1.23 V (Eq. S15 for η OER and Eq. S16 for η ORR). The OER and ORR overpotentials of 4d-TM@g-C3N3 are summarized in Fig. 2 a–b. Generally speaking, lower overpotential indicates better electrocatalytic performance in thermodynamics. On this basis, Pd N × @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh N • @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int • @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int • @ C 3 N 3 demonstrate high OER performance, exhibiting η OER of 0.43, 0.56, 0.40,0.59, and 0.66 V, respectively. These values are comparable and surpass the overpotential of the state-of-the-art RuO2 catalyst, which is 0.69 V (Fig. S11), indicating their significant potential as effective OER catalysts. At the same time Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , R h i n t ∙ @ C 3 N 3 and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , exhibits excellent ORR catalytic performance with η ORR of 0.56, 0.37, 0.44, and 0.37 V, compared to the conventional noble metal catalyst Pt(111) (0.61 V, Fig. S11). Notably, the η OER = 0.59 V and η ORR = 0.44 V value of the charged system ( Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 ) is lower than its neutral system, Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 system (η OER = 0.66 V, η ORR = 0.56 V), indicating that it is very necessary to consider the charged system. In the study of OER and ORR, understanding the implications of the potential effects on free energy, overpotential, and charge is crucial. The potential effects on scaling relations are equally significant, which describe the linear correlation between the ΔG *OH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH. Specifically, in OER processes, the ΔG *OH vs. ΔG *O, as well as in ORR processes ΔG *OH vs. ΔG *OOH, typically exhibit linear correlation. Fig. S12 presents these correlations through precise scaling relations. Fig. S12a illustrates a strong linear relationship between ΔG *O and ΔG *OH (OER), represented by the equation ΔG *O = 1.75ΔG *OH + 0.64, with a correlation coefficient (R 2) of 0.90. Similarly, Fig. S12b depicts the relationship between ΔG *OOH and ΔG *OH (ORR), which can be expressed as ΔG *OOH = 0.71ΔG *OH + 3.47, with R 2 of 0.88. Further, the relationship between the η OER and η ORR of 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3, and the adsorption energies of intermediates is detailed in Fig. S12. Notably, the relationship between −η OER and the ΔG *O − ΔG *OH exhibits a volcanic shape, reflecting the PDS of OER—namely, the production of *O and the decomposition of H2O in most systems studied. Conversely, the correlation between −η ORR and ΔG *OH for ORR also forms a 'volcano' diagram. This pattern occurs due to the PDS of ORR involving the synthesis of H2O and the production of *OOH. Additionally, Fig. S12c highlights that η OER for R h N ∙ @ C 3 N 3 is closest to the volcano's peak, suggesting favorable adsorption of *O compared to other systems. Similarly, Fig. S12d shows that η ORR for Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 and P d i n t ∙ @ C 3 N 3 are near the peak, attributed to the optimal ΔG *OH values observed. Considering the obtained relationship ΔG *OOH = 0.71ΔG *OH + 3.47 (Fig. S12b), the four free energy changes (Eqs. S13a–d) can be modified as follows: (1a) Δ G 1 = Δ G ∗ OH (1b) Δ G 2 = Δ G ∗ O - Δ G ∗ OH (1c) Δ G 3 = - ( Δ G ∗ O - Δ G ∗ OH ) - 0.29 Δ G ∗ OH + 3.47 (1d) Δ G 4 = - 0.71 Δ G ∗ OH + 1.45 Hence, the OER and ORR activities (refer to Table S7) can be characterized by two factors: ΔG *O − ΔG *OH and ΔG *OH. Consequently, the η OER and η ORR of the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems (refer to Table S7) can be represented in contour maps based on ΔG *O − ΔG *OH and ΔG *OH. As depicted in Fig. 2c,d, a critical feature of these maps is the borderline overpotential, which suggests that two adjacent elementary reactions exhibit equivalent rate-determining characteristics. Each plot is segmented into four distinct zones by black dashed lines, corresponding to the four elementary steps of the OER/ORR processes. Positioning a catalyst within a specific zone indicates the PDS of systems within the catalytic cycle. Additionally, the regions marked in red within the contour maps indicate lower η OER and η ORR values. In this regard, the contour maps can intuitively identify the PDS and activity of a given catalyst. Specifically, in Fig. 2c, the PDS for the OER predominantly involves the transitions from *OH to *O and from *O to *OOH, highlighting the significant role of the radical *O species. Conversely, for the ORR, as shown in Fig. 2d, the PDS predominantly occurs at the initial reaction step (* + O2 → *OOH) and the final hydrogenation step (*OH → H2O) for both 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3. These observations are corroborated by data presented in Table S7, reinforcing our findings' reliability. For the OER (Fig. 2c), R h N ∙ @ C 3 N 3 is noted to be closest to this optimal region, with a calculated η OER of 0.40 V. Similarly, for the ORR (Fig. 2d), both Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 are nearest to the red area. Their η ORR are both 0.37 V, which are the lowest. 3.3 Machine learning In this study, we applied ML to establish a correlation between the bifunctional OER/ORR activity and the physical and chemical properties of 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems, as illustrated in Fig. 3 a. We selected fourteen properties of 4d-TM atoms and categorized them into two primary groups [58]. The first group includes five atomic size and structural properties: electronegativity (N m), electron affinity (χ m), first ionization energy (I m), the radius of the TM atom (r d), and the number of TM-d electrons (N e). Additionally, we included descriptors related to chemical properties derived from DFT calculations, such as the d-band center (ε d), the total magnetic moment (μ B0), and the magnetic moments of the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems with oxygenated intermediates (μB -OH, μB -O, μB -OOH) (Table S8), as well as the bond lengths between TM and coordination atoms (d TM-OH, d TM-O, and d TM-OOH), and the charge transfer of TM aomts (Qe ) (Table S9). Due to the linear relationship between ΔG *OH, ΔG *O, and ΔG *OOH (Fig. S12), we chose ΔG *OH as target data and divided 20 data points into 17 for training and 3 for testing. The training sets are used to develop ML models, while the testing sets evaluate model performance. We employed four algorithms for our predictive analysis: GBR, RFR, SVR, and KNR. A cross-validation approach is used to determine the optimal model configuration by assessing combinations of the R 2 and the root-mean-square error (RMSE), which serve as metrics for evaluating the algorithms' predictive accuracy. Fig. 3b and Fig. S13 present a comparative analysis of the RMSE and R 2 scores achieved by different algorithms. The GBR model demonstrated superior performance with the lowest RMSE values (0.027 V for training and 0.153 V for test) and the highest R 2 scores (0.999 V for training and 0.968 V for test), indicating precise prediction. Further validation of the GBR model's accuracy is provided in Fig. 3c, which compares the DFT-calculated and GBR-predicted ΔG *OH. The distributions for the training set (represented by red squares) and the test set (represented by blue circles) align closely, displaying a linear relationship. This indicates that the GBR model can reliably predict the catalytic activity of 4d-TM@C3N3 systems. Consequently, we utilize the GBR model for subsequent ORR and OER catalytic activity predictions and the mechanism analysis. The conclusions drawn from the GBR analysis are presented in Fig. 3d. Notably, d TM-O, d TM-OH, Ne , Im , and Qe are identified as the most significant descriptors, with feature importance of 18.83 %, 14.06 %, 13.94 %, 13.58 %, and 12.40 %, collectively accounting for over 72.81 %. Among them, d TM-O, d TM-OH, and Qe are associated with the chemical properties and obtained from DFT calculations, whereas Ne and Im are fundamental period table values. This suggests that one can estimate the electrocatalytic performance of a given TM@C3N3 before carrying out any explicit DFT calculations. These insights offer two advantages: (1) preliminary screening of catalytic activity using descriptor distributions from ML training, reducing reliance on computationally intensive DFT calculations, (2) guiding material optimization and improving predictive model accuracy for future research. 3.4 OER/ORR bifunctional activity As depicted in Fig. 4 a, we analyzed the combined bifunctional catalytic performance (η Bi) across thirty 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems in different charge states (Fig. 1e). Here, η Bi, defined as the sum of η OER and η ORR, serves as a metric to evaluate the bifunctional catalytic performance [59]. A lower η Bi value indicates improved catalytic activity. In Fig. 4a, Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 exhibit low η Bi values of 0.93, 1.03, and 1.03 V, which are comparable to benchmark catalysts such as Ru/C (1.01 V) [60], 1D-Co2O4 (0.85 V) [60], NiO/CoN (0.85 V) [61], and 20 % Ir/C (0.92 V) [62]. We calculated the ΔG of the overall OER and ORR reaction at the applied potentials of 0, 1.23, and PDS (V) for Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 systems, which are shown in Fig. S14. Considering the strong correlation effects in transition metals, we further refined the overpotential calculations using the GGA + SOL + U approach [28]. These findings listed in Fig. S15 confirm the consistency of GGA + SOL and GGA + SOL + U methods in predicting η OER/η ORR, aligning with earlier detailed calculations [51–53,63]. Electrocatalysts must exhibit structural stability and exceptional performance to be effective in OER and ORR applications. In this regard, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were conducted at 300 K over 8 ps to assess the thermodynamic stability of Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 . The results, as illustrated in Fig. S16, show no significant geometric deformations or bond dissociation appear, and the total energy and temperature of these systems remain stable around their equilibrium values, confirming their dynamic stability at room temperature. Furthermore, we calculated the cluster energy (E clus) and dissolution potential (U diss) to evaluate the structural stability from thermodynamic and electrochemical perspectives [64]. The calculation details are listed in Note S5. For a catalyst to be deemed both thermodynamically and electrochemically stable, the criteria of E clus < 0 eV and U diss > 0 V must be satisfied. As demonstrated in Fig. 2c–d, Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 showcase robust stability under C- and N-rich conditions. The synthetic practicability for the three candidates is also a crucial consideration. Encouragingly, TM SACs on graphitic carbon nitrides such as g-C2N [65], g-C3N4 [66,67], and C4N [68] have been experimentally synthesized. This suggests that TM@C3N3 can be experimentally realized using TMCl2 or other TM salts as precursors via the wet chemistry method [14]. Furthermore, the formation energies of Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 are less than −0.085 eV under N-rich conditions, which are much more negative than that of the synthesized Ru@g-C3N4 [69] and Pt@g-C3N4 [70] (3.12 and 2.88 eV, respectively) [52]. Therefore, the experimental synthesis of Rhint@C3N3 and Ptint@C3N3 is highly feasible. Consequently, these systems are identified as promising candidates for high-performance bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts. 3.5 Origin of OER/ORR activity The ML results indicated that three chemical properties, including d TM-O, d TM-OH, and Qe , significantly influence the electrocatalytic performance of TM@C3N3. Thus, we performed a comprehensive analysis focused on the adsorption configuration of *O and *OH, supplemented by Bader charge analysis to assess Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 . The results of this analysis are presented in Fig. 5 a–d and Table S11. The Bader charge analysis indicated a predominant charge transfer pathway from the TM to the oxygenated intermediates. This observation suggests a stable interaction between the oxygen and TM atoms within the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 frameworks. Notably, the Qe of the charged catalysts Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 are found to be higher than that of their neutral counterparts. This implies that adjusting the Fermi level towards the valence band, as depicted in Fig. 1a–d, facilitates the modulation of the charge states within the 4d-TMN@C3N3, and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems. Such adjustments are crucial for tuning Qe and thereby enhancing the bifunctional catalytic activity for both the OER and ORR. To elucidate the role of charge state modifications on the electronic properties, we conducted comprehensive density of states (DOS) calculations for Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 , Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 . Recognizing the limitations of the GGA method in accurately predicting band gaps, we employed the Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) screened hybrid functional. This approach provides a refined description of the electronic structure by adjusting the Hartree-Fock mixing parameter (α) within the range of 0.12–0.3. Our optimized value, α = 0.242, yielded a calculated band gap for g-C3N3 of 2.89 eV, which is consistent with previous findings reported in the literature [71]. The total density of states (TDOS) and partial density of states (PDOS) for these catalyst systems are detailed in Fig. 5e–h, while the corresponding results utilizing the GGA functional are provided for comparison in Fig. S17. Additionally, the PDOS of 4d-TM in the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems across various charge states are explored in Figs. S18 and S19. The ε d parameter, often considered a key catalytic activity descriptor, is calculated, and the values are presented in Table S12. Our findings indicate significant variations in ε d for the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems, suggesting that both the charge states and the specific 4d-TM involved strongly influence the adsorption capabilities. Moreover, we investigated the total magnetic properties of the 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 before and after the adsorption of oxygenated intermediates, with findings summarized in Table S11. Our results demonstrate that the magnetic characteristics are predominantly derived from the 4d-TM states, influenced by the asymmetry in the spin-up and spin-down channels. As shown in Fig. 5e–h, the band gaps for Rh int × @ C 3 N 3 (2.94 eV, displayed in Fig. 5e, η Bi = 1.22 V) and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 (2.91 eV, displayed in Fig. 5h, η Bi = 1.03 V) are observed to be wider compared to Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 (2.83 eV, displayed in Fig. 5f, η Bi = 1.03 V) and Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 (2.70 eV, displayed in Fig. 5g, η Bi = 0.93 V), respectively. This suggests that in 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems, the smaller η Bi correlates with a lower band gap, likely due to the systems with better OER/ORR catalytic performance having stronger electron mobility. Electrons near the valence band can more easily acquire the energy needed to cross the smaller band gap to the conduction band, a process that high temperatures can further facilitate by increasing semiconductor conductivity [72]. Therefore, reducing the band gap could enhance electrical conductivity in these catalysts, potentially improving their electrocatalytic performance. 4 Conclusion This work employs first-principles calculations to explore the catalytic activity of 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems for bifunctional OER/ORR. We demonstrate that 4d-TMs can be stably incorporated into g-C3N3. The formation energies, ΔG, η, and electronic structures of both 4d-TMN@C3N3 and 4d-TMint@C3N3 systems are investigated, including comparisons between their neutral and charged states. Our analysis reveals that systems such as Pd int × @ C 3 N 3 , Rh int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 and Pd int ∙ @ C 3 N 3 exhibit dual functionality to catalyze OER and ORR with relatively low overpotentials of 0.56, 0.59, 0.66 V for OER and 0.37, 0.44, 0.37 V for ORR, respectively. These findings indicate that the Pd and Rh-doped C3N3 systems hold significant potential as bifunctional OER/ORR catalysts. The performance is not only influenced by the choice of doped 4d TM but also by the formation energies, charge states, and the Fermi level positioning. Adjusting these charge states by modulating the Fermi level closer to the valence band can enhance the catalyst's charge transfer properties, optimizing OER/ORR functions. Furthermore, insights from machine learning analysis highlight that the d TM-O, d TM-OH and Q e are the highest relevance as descriptors. The findings in this study suggest that inducing a charge at defect sites can significantly enhance the activity of 4d-TM doped g-C3N3, paving the way for the design of more efficient bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Designing efficient and stable bifunctional oxygen evolution/reduction reaction (OER/ORR) electrocatalysts is important to developing renewable energy technologies. However, integrating OER/ORR activity in a single electrocatalyst remains challenging due to the difficulty in balancing the adsorption strengths of reaction intermediates. Herein, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to investigate 4d-transition metal (TM) doped graphitic carbon nitride (4d-TM@C3N3) systems as potential bifunctional OER/ORR electrocatalysts by considering the charge states through a defect physics method. Our results identified 30 stable 4d-TMN@C3N3 systems, including TM doped at nitrogen sites (4d-TMN@C3N3) and those occupying interstitial sites (4d-TMint@C3N3). Machine learning analysis showed that the the bond lengths between TM and O (d TM-O) and OH (d TM-OH), and the charge transfer of TM atoms (Q e) are the three primary descriptors characterizing the adsorption behavior. Among these, Pdint ×@C3N3 (Pd interstitial site, neutral charge state), Pdint •@C3N3 (Pd interstitial site, +1 charge state), and Rhint •@C3N3 (Rh interstitial site, +1 charge state) exhibit outstanding OER/ORR catalytic activity with η OER/η ORR of 0.56/0.37 V, 0.66/0.37 V, and 0.59/0.44 V, respectively, which are comparable to benchmark electrocatalysts such as RuO2 for OER (0.69 V) and Pt for ORR (0.61 V). The enhanced performance arises from charged defects adjustment that optimizes the bifunctional OER/ORR activity, offering potential electrocatalysts for energy conversion applications.
